nbme_correct_explanation: Congenital hypothyroidism typically presents without symptoms due to placental crossing of maternal thyroid hormone. However, if hypothyroidism is left untreated, infants may develop lethargy, hypothermia, feeding problems, hoarse cry, myxedematous facies, macroglossia, hypotonia, umbilical hernia, prolonged jaundice caused by impaired feeding and decreased bilirubin conjugation, and dry skin. In patients with decreased thyroid hormone concentrations on serum testing, thyroid scans and thyroid-binding globulin concentrations help elucidate the cause of hypothyroidism (eg, distinguishing between thyroid dysgenesis and defective thyroid hormone synthesis). Management requires proactive newborn screening and levothyroxine therapy.
nbme_incorrect_explanation: A karyotype analysis (Choice A) would be helpful in the diagnosis of chromosomal diseases such as Turner syndrome, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, or trisomy 21. Measurement of sweat chloride concentration (Choice B) is used in the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Cystic fibrosis is a hereditary chloride channelopathy that results in thickened bronchial and gastrointestinal mucous secretions, leading to chronic infection, inflammation, and malabsorption. CT scan of the head (Choice D) can help with the evaluation of structural brain abnormalities such as intracranial hemorrhage or congenital malformations. It has no role in the diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism. CT scan of the liver (Choice E) would not be helpful in the evaluation of congenital hypothyroidism. Jaundice secondary to biliary obstruction can be evaluated with ultrasonography of the right upper quadrant of the abdomen.

In the United States, it is most associated with undercooked poultry, eggs, or meats, and in some cases has been associated with pets (eg, turtles, reptiles, chickens). The incubation period typically ranges from 8 to 72 hours and patients will subsequently develop diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and fever. Bloody stools are common in children and Salmonella gastroenteritis is usually self-limited, with fevers resolving within 3 days and diarrhea resolving in approximately 1 week. Stool studies may show gram negative bacilli.

Patients are treated with supportive care and diagnosis is confirmed by stool cultures.

Escherichia coli 0157:H? (Choice B) is associated with Shiga toxin and outbreaks of bloody diarrhea. The patient's course may be complicated by hemolytic uremic syndrome, which presents with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and kidney failure.

Patients may also present with fevers, abdominal distention, and cramping, and diagnosis is made with a stool culture. Antimotility agents are not recommended for affected patients as they may worsen symptoms.

In the hospital setting, erythromycin eye drops are provided to newborns at the time of delivery to prevent gonococcal conjunctivitis. Newborns diagnosed with gonococcal conjunctivitis should be hospitalized, cultures should be obtained, and patients should be provided ceftriaxone. Chemical conjunctivitis (Choice B) may be the result of chemicals meeting the conjunctiva. Symptoms including erythema, redness, pruritus or pain, and watery discharge may be present. In general, once the chemical has been washed from the eye, symptoms improve. Chlorine is a common self-limited cause of chemical conjunctivitis.

nbme_correct_explanation: Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin that plays an important role in the synthesis of several coagulation factors, including factors 11, VII, IX, and X, as well as proteins C and S. Primary sources of vitamin K include leafy green vegetables and endogenous production by intestinal bacterial flora. Vitamin K deficiency is common in newborns due to poor placental transfer of vitamin K, low concentrations of vitamin K in breast milk, as well as immature neonatal intestinal flora and poor absorption. Vitamin K deficiency presents with signs and symptoms of bleeding (also known as hemorrhagic disease of the newborn), which may include cutaneous bleeding (eg, bruising, petechiae, oozing from venipuncture sites), hematomas, epistaxis, or gastrointestinal, retroperitoneal, or intracranial hemorrhage. All newborns should be administered prophylaxis with intramuscular vitamin K. Newborns with evidence of bleeding should be treated with oral or intravenous replacement of vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma (FFP), although treatment should be tailored according to the type and severity of bleeding. FFP contains all coagulation factors, as well as fibrinogen and proteins C and S.
nbme_incorrect_explanation:
Cryoprecipitate (Choice A) contains concentrated fibrinogen along with factors VIII and XIII, and von Willebrand factor. It is commonly used for the treatment of coagulopathic states with decreased concentrations of fibrinogen and factor VIII, such as disseminated intravascular coagulation. Cryoprecipitate does not contain the coagulation factors that are affected by vitamin K deficiency, such as factors 11, VII, IX, and X, or proteins C and S.

Factor VIII concentrate (Choice B) is useful for the treatment of bleeding disorders that are characterized by a deficiency of factor VIII, such as hemophilia A and von Willebrand disease.

Lactated Ringer solution (Choice D) is a crystalloid solution that is useful for the repletion of intravascular volume. While volume repletion may be useful in the setting of intravascular volume loss for hemorrhage, correcting the deficiency of coagulation factors by administering FFP is a more important step toward addressing this patient's underlying disease.

Platelets (Choice E) is incorrect. While vitamin K deficiency is associated with deficiency of many coagulation factors, it does not result in thrombocytopenia.

nbme_correct_explanation: Pyloric stenosis is a disorder of the pyloric sphincter that occurs in young infants and can result in partial or complete gastric outlet obstruction. It is caused by hypertrophy of the pylorus and an inability to relax the pyloric sphincter. Infants classically present within the first 1 to 2 months of life with forceful nonbilious emesis. Physical examination is notable for a characteristic ovoid mass in the epigastric region. The recurrent emesis, if severe, may result in signs of volume depletion and malnutrition. Laboratory studies typically show a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis as a result of the loss of gastric hydrochloric acid and potassium ions. Additionally, the resultant volume depletion causes activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, resulting in renal losses of potassium and protons. Confirmatory diagnosis is made by ultrasound imaging to evaluate the thickness and length of the pyloric muscle. Patients are treated with surgical pyloromyotomy to relieve the stenosis.
nbme_incorrect_explanation:
Duodenum (Choice A) is the location of obstruction in patients with duodenal atresia, which is caused by failure of recanalization of the duodenal lumen. Duodenal atresia presents with vomiting and abdominal distension within the first few days after birth in complete atresia.

Gastroesophageal junction (Choice B) is the location of obstruction in achalasia. Achalasia is an esophageal dysmotility disorder resulting from deficient peristalsis as a result of impaired neuromuscular transmission and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter. It manifests as dysphagia, odynophagia, weight loss, halitosis, and regurgitation of undigested food. It is typically diagnosed between ages 25 and 65 years and is rare in children.

Jejunum (Choice C) may undergo atresia in a fetus secondary to an ischemic event, which may have various causes, such as maternal cocaine use, malrotation with volvulus, or other idiopathic causes. Patients may present with vomiting and abdominal distension on the first day of life, similar to patients with duodenal atresia.

Midesophagus (Choice D) is the location of obstruction in patients with a vascular ring. A vascular ring is a congenital malformation of the aortic arch and/or great vessels that encircles the trachea and midesophagus. In addition to dysphagia, vomiting, and feeding problems, patients may present with strider and respiratory difficulties.

nbme_correct_explanation: Pyloric stenosis is a disorder of the pyloric sphincter that occurs in young infants and can result in partial or complete gastric outlet obstruction. It is caused by hypertrophy of the pylorus and an inability to relax the pyloric sphincter. Infants classically present within the first 1 to 2 months of life with forceful, nonbilious emesis. Physical examination is notable for a characteristic ovoid mass in the epigastric region. The recurrent emesis, if severe, may result in signs of volume depletion and malnutrition. Laboratory studies typically show a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis caused by the loss of gastric hydrochloric acid and potassium ions. Additionally, the resultant volume depletion causes activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, resulting in renal losses of potassium and protons. Confirmatory diagnosis is made with ultrasonography to evaluate the thickness and length of the pyloric muscle. Patients are treated with surgical pyloromyotomy to relieve the stenosis.

Symptoms of hyperammonemia in infants include somnolence and vomiting. If severe, hyperammonemia can lead to cerebral edema.
Acute viral gastroenteritis (Choice B) often presents with vomiting and diarrhea with or without fever. This patient with progressive and forceful emesis occurring only after feeding has a presentation more consistent with gastric outlet obstruction.
Gastroesophageal reflux (Choice C) disease (GERO) is caused by acid reflux into the lower esophagus. This commonly occurs as a result of increased intraabdominal pressure or diminished closing pressure of the lower esophageal sphincter permitting acidic contents of the stomach to reflux into the esophagus. The patient is cooperative, polite, and in no acute distress. On mental status examination, he says he is "tired of this dialysis and all my other medical problems." He has a full range of affect, but it is primarily serious. His thought process is linear and goal directed. His cognitive function is intact. He confirms that he wants to end hemodialysis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in addressing this patient's desire to end therapy?
A) Contact the patient's daughter
B) Contact the patient's son
C) Contact the patient's wife
D) Consult the state probate court
E) Discontinue hemodialysis
nbme_correct_explanation: Physicians should respect patient autonomy. This principle is especially pertinent when the patient is an adult without evidence of psychiatric or medical conditions that impair basic decision-making capabilities. Though patients may make decisions physicians deem as poor medical judgment, the ethical principle of autonomy dictates that patients have the right to make these decisions. Coercive treatment is only warranted when patients experience medical or psychiatric conditions that interfere with their ability to make decisions. This patient has intact cognitive function and appears to possess decisional capacity to end hemodialysis in that he is able to appropriately verbalize his reasoning for ending hemodialysis (valuing his quality of life).
nbme_incorrect_explanation: Contacting the patient's daughter, son, or wife (Choices A, B, and C) is unnecessary, as the physician should respect the patient's autonomy. If the patient lacked decisional capacity, his durable power of attorney (his son) (Choice B) should be contacted first for substitute decision making. However, the patient is a consenting adult who appears to have decisional capacity to end hemodialysis. Consulting the state probate court (Choice D) would only be warranted if the patient lacked decisional capacity and had no next of kin (substitute decision makers).
